content.question: A small metal sphere with net charge <math alttext="negative 5 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>nC</mtext></mstyle></math> is located inside and concentric with a large metal shell that has a net charge of <math alttext="positive 9 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>nC</mtext></mstyle></math>, as shown in the cross-section diagram. Part of the net charge on the shell is found on its interior surface and part is found on its exterior surface. Which of the following explains why the interior surface of the shell has a different amount of charge than the exterior surface of the shell?

choices.label: The quantization property of charge makes it impossible for the total amount to be split into two equal parts.
The shell is a conductor, so all positive charge will move to the interior surface under the effect of the negatively charged small sphere.
The surface charge density is the same for all parts of the shell, and because the interior surface area is less than the exterior surface area there is more charge on the outer surface.
Only a particular amount of charge located on the interior surface results in zero electric flux through the metal material of the shell.

content.answer: Only a particular amount of charge located on the interior surface results in zero electric flux through the metal material of the shell.
